header_summary:
Christopher Allen's announcement highlights Blockchain Commons' efforts in integrating FROST signatures with Bitcoin's Taproot, enhancing multisignature efficiency and resilience. This development was shared in anticipation of a demonstration at the upcoming Gordian meeting, which also aims to address the architectural and security challenges associated with this integration. Furthermore, Blockchain Commons is extending its educational initiatives to include FROST and BDK technologies, promoting broader developer engagement and practical experimentation ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CACrqygC5925FrJ5WN=986Bni5+0zZ7YeC_EqAXyao=u5rK3P_A@mail.gmail.com/T/#u#m9cde5186fa3252c00d5051a72924b5931f416660)).

Murch casts doubt on the practicality and necessity of indefinitely retaining information on unconfirmed Bitcoin transactions, pointing out that confirmed transactions are what truly affect the network's shared state. This skepticism extends to the utility of tracking such transactions without a solid mechanism for validation or rebroadcast, suggesting that these considerations may be more suitably discussed on platforms dedicated to Bitcoin, like [Bitcoin Stack Exchange](https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com).

Sanket1729 discusses the implications of Simplicity, a programming language for blockchain smart contracts, noting its powerful but low-level nature that complicates usability. To address this, SimplicityHL has been introduced, offering a higher-level language experience similar to Rust, thereby simplifying the development of smart contracts on blockchain platforms like Liquid. This development, exemplified by a non-interactive fee bumping mechanism in smart contracts, showcases the potential of SimplicityHL to streamline secure and auditable contract creation, with further resources available for interested developers ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/writing-simplicity-programs-with-simplicityhl/1900)).

Glozow and David Taubmann touch on broader concerns within the Bitcoin ecosystem, from the potential policy adjustments to include free or non-standard transactions, to the critical examination of Bitcoin's decentralization ethos amidst growing institutional influence. These discussions reflect ongoing debates about the balance between security, flexibility, and the foundational principles of decentralization in the face of evolving market dynamics and technological advancements ([source 1](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/changing-the-minimum-relay-feerate/1886/4), [source 2](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/paralel-bitcoin-only-for-conscious-living-individuals/1877/13)).

recent_posts.title: [ann] FROST Signing for Bitcoin: Demo + Taproot Integration Discussion @ Aug 6 Gordian Call
recent_posts.summary:
- Blockchain Commons integrates FROST with Bitcoin, enhancing resilience and efficiency, with a demo on August 6th.
- The Gordian meeting will discuss FROST signature tweaks for Bitcoin's Taproot, focusing on architectural and security concerns.
- The initiative extends educational resources on FROST and BDK technologies to developers, along with a dedicated FROST page for further exploration.

recent_posts.title: Proposal: Self-Verifiable Transaction Broadcast Log for Enhanced User Transparency
recent_posts.summary:
- The email discusses the impracticality of indefinitely storing unconfirmed Bitcoin transactions data.
- It questions how unconfirmed transactions' validity can be verified without documentation.
- It suggests discussing such technicalities on dedicated platforms like Bitcoin Stack Exchange.

recent_posts.title: Writing Simplicity Programs with SimplicityHL
recent_posts.summary:
- Simplicity is designed for blockchain smart contracts but challenging to use due to its functional, low-level nature.
- SimplicityHL, a more accessible high-level language for Simplicity, facilitates writing smart contracts with a syntax like Rust.
- It demonstrates non-interactive fee bumping in Bitcoin transactions, enhancing smart contract functionality without external inputs.

recent_posts.title: Changing the minimum relay feerate
recent_posts.summary:
- Miners may start confirming free transactions, extending potential transaction sizes up to 4MB.
- The discussion includes possible acceptance of non-standard transactions if supported by miners.
- Skepticism exists about the practicality of new requirements for signing devices due to significant work needed.

recent_posts.title: Paralel Bitcoin only for conscious living individuals
recent_posts.summary:
- The concern highlights Bitcoin's decentralization issue and control by Western oligarchs.
- It suggests Bitcoin benefits financial institutions and possibly Satoshi Nakamoto, undermining decentralization.
- Strategic interventions are deemed necessary to maintain Bitcoin's decentralization amid institutional involvement.

active_posts.title: A Taproot-native (re-)bindable transaction bundle proposal
active_posts.summary:
- Poinsot, Roose, and Sanders developed a Bitcoin proposal enhancing key functionalities.
- Their work introduces `OP_TEMPLATEHASH`, a Taproot-native operation simplifying existing mechanisms.
- Documentation and rationale for `OP_TEMPLATEHASH` are detailed in external BIP texts and pull requests.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Utreexo Nodes
active_posts.summary:
- Tadge Dryja, Davidson Souza, and Calvin Kim propose three Bitcoin Improvement Proposals emphasizing Utreexo.
- Utreexo enables transaction verification without the entire Unspent Transaction Output set, improving blockchain efficiency.
- They seek community feedback on these conceptual BIPs via GitHub to refine their approach for a scalable blockchain.

active_posts.title: Taproot is post-quantum secure when restricted to script-path spends
active_posts.summary:
- A study found Bitcoin's Taproot secure against quantum attacks using the QROM, discounting SHA256 vulnerabilities.
- It proposes a two-phase softfork for Bitcoin, initially adding post-quantum signatures, then disabling Schnorr and ECDSA pre-large-scale quantum computing.
- The paper states a quantum attacker needs at least 2^92 machines for a 50% success rate against Taproot, focusing future security concerns on classical computing advancements.

active_posts.title: Exploring Extended Relative Timelocks
active_posts.summary:
- Users of Liana explore extending Bitcoin's timelocks to ~10 years due to demand.
- A method suggests using bit 21 in `nSequence` for longer timelocks, multiplying duration by 8.
- The experiment includes a tool for creating compatible transactions, with feedback and alternatives discussed.

active_posts.title: Fee-Based Spam Prevention For Lightning
active_posts.summary:
- Jager and Teinturier proposed Upfront and Time-Dependent Reverse Hold Fees for the LN.
- Enhancements include secret confirmations and burn outputs to secure fee allocation and promote cooperation.
- The advanced protocols establish a framework for precise, incentive-based fee assignment within the LN.

today_in_history_posts.title: On a new community process to specify covenants
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Antoine Riard proposed a decentralized investigation process on bitcoin-dev.
- The process includes IRC discussions, in-person meetups, and six development phases.
- Results are published for community feedback, with potential for proposal revision.

today_in_history_posts.title: Splice Pinning Prevention w/o Anchors
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Anchor outputs were introduced to mitigate mempool pinning risks in lightning.
- Splice transactions require v0 P2SH witness scripts with `1 CSV` to avoid pinning attacks.
- The interactive tx protocol mandates RBF for splice transactions, enhancing fee bumping methods.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin scaling involves creating 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for large user transactions.
- Off-chain solutions are preferred due to high main chain transaction costs and scalability issues.
- Development focuses on enhancing security, efficiency, and regulatory compliance of these solutions.
